note.p: Hand (MS VII)—This fair copy is in the hand of John James Ruskin. On the line following the end of the poem, he added the date 1833, presumably referring to the date of the Tour of 1833, although conceivably referring also to the date of composition and even transcription. See the apparatuses for MS VII and Account of a Tour on the Continent: Manuscripts

While the variant in the print versions may be owing to a faulty transcription or a printerʼs error, it is possible that W. G. Collingwood made the change deliberately in order to improve sense. While the original parallel structure in the manuscript seems superior, with the prepositional phrases in lines 9 and 11 paired with their respective main clauses in lines 10 and 12, Collingwood perhaps recognized that it is geographically erroneous to state that the Rhine foams from Rhaetian and Dinaric crests in the west, since the Dinaric Alps lie in the east, across the Adriatic sea (see contextual glosses), far from the course of the Rhine. Thus, by changing the parallelism to a series of three consecutive prepositional phrases, each of them modifying the same main clause in line 12, Collingwood would have created a poetic sense of scanning the horizon of the entire Alpine chain—if not precisely correcting the accuracy or grammar of the original.

It is notable that, while the editors of the Library Edition rejected Collingwoodʼs alteration of line 7 (returning to the awkward but original “In all its aspect is as fair” in preference to Collingwoodʼs more elegant but invented “In all its aspects ʼtis as fair!”), they nonetheless silently retained his change in line 10 from “Foam” to “From”—perhaps an oversight, or perhaps an implicit acknowledgement of the improved sense.
